abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Utilities Sector Reform
            Project for Lesotho were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: to
            keep the momentum in the telecom reform and to close the gap
            between the mountainous areas and the lowlands, targets for
            rural access to telecom should be established with the
            operators. The universal access fund should be established
            with clear set operators' charges and targets. The slow
            uptake of electricity connections in the pilot areas showed
            that demand studies, i.e. willingness to pay studies as
            preparation for the pilots often do not reflect reality.
            More detailed planning techniques, including financial
            planning and calculation of subsidies will have to be
            developed. The late start of the rural pilots also prevented
            the project to perform impact evaluations that should still
            be performed. The next phase should include relevant skills
            for income generation and productive use of electricity. It
            will also be important that the Government clarified the
            future of the Rural Electrification Unit, the National Rural
            Electrification Fund (NREF), so that donor and private
            sector funds could be harnessed and leveraged.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Utilities Sector Reform Project will
            seek to improve business infrastructure, particularly in
            electricity, and telecommunications services, including
            provisions for internet connections, to foster private
            foreign, and domestic capital development. The components
            will: 1) upgrade the electricity sector, through new
            technology, and management practices. Private capital
            inflows will foster improvements, and access to reliable
            electricity services, and, technical assistance (TA) will be
            provided by an Interim Management Task force, to manage the
            Lesotho Electricity Corporation (LEC); a sales advisory
            group will develop a divestiture strategy for LEC, providing
            expertise in banking, international law, and technical
            issues. LEC streamlining involve retrenchment payments,
            which includes training for retrenched employees, and for
            retained employees regarding implementation of
            restructuring/downsizing programs; 2) support regulatory
            reforms, to enforce appropriate regulations in the utilities
            sectors, ensure fair treatment of sector operators, and
            encourage transfer of technologies, and private investments;
            3) finance a study to recommend options regarding the
            hydroelectric power, and export potential; and, assess the
            feasibility of electricity access to areas not commercially
            viable; 4) establish an Investment Fund/Unit Trust, and,
            provide TA to support regional integration, through income
            generating activities in the sectors; 5) provide advisory
            services, and capacity building; and, 6) provide financial,
            auditing, and legal support during implementation, in
            addition to Project Preparation Facility refinancing options.

repnme.cdata!:
Lesotho - Utilities Sector Reform Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The only aspect of the Utilities Sector
            Reform Project, that is of some environmental concern,
            regards the rural, and urban hookups, and related
            activities, therefore this environmental assessment reviews
            the potential adverse effects, mainly, on highland
            ecosystems, threatening its flora, and fauna, which include
            endemic species of plants, a rich variety of medicinal
            plants, and herbs, and aquatic life, covering significant
            habitats. Environmental adversity already include soil
            erosion, and land degradation, loss of organic content, and
            nutrients due to poor agricultural practices, and various
            forms of bio-mass removal, thus water-holding capacity is
            reduced. Degraded rangelands have given way to
            deforestation, causing water run-off, reduced infiltration,
            and low groundwater levels. Mitigating measures include: 1)
            appropriate engineering design should avoid slope sites to
            prevent soil erosion, while construction activity will be
            conducted only during the dry season, and, re-vegetation
            will be practiced as needed; 2) electric pole placement, and
            power lines will avoid natural habitats to prevent
            bio-diversity losses, ensuring that micro-topography
            restores site conditions caused by flooding, and drainage
            disruption; 3) safe, and proper storage of equipment, and
            construction materials, should prevent soil, and water
            contamination resulting from lubricant, or chemical leakage,
            to protect public health, aquatic ecosystems, and habitats;
            and, 4) socioeconomic impacts will be minimized by ensuring
            that alignments will not require resettlement; that
            agricultural lands will be avoided, and/or compacted soil
            will be restored as needed.
